title: Are you a Communist, Socialist or capitalist and why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are you a Communist, Socialist or capitalist and why? Well Richard Bradley your question emphasizes the corruption of knowledge that exist in the world today, making complication where ‘institutionalized ignorance’ has replaced knowledge as the basis of academia. The three points of you question, magnify the lack of knowledge that is so common in America today. Communism and Socialism are synonyms for what? They identify the slavery of all the citizens to the desires of the state, noting else. While the word capitalism is only emphasizes the lack of knowledge Marx had, making up words to identify what he didn’t know. The result, Marx created a word to identify his demagoguery lacking any foundations for its meaning. The why, he had no idea how commerce and enterprise work. As for the word…created by Marx…of capitalism, as he didn’t know what he was expressing, it gets a bit difficult to know what he was talking about. In my experience, I first read…or attempted to read…the Communist Manifesto in the 7th grade. As I had a job since I was in the 4th grade, this fiction made little sense to me. The results were words that made no sense. Later in life, after my undergraduate degree, once more, I read it, with more understanding of enterprise, and commerce, my conclusion was the same as the 7th grade with the results words that made no sense. Having lived in the world for three score, ten and a few more years, most of which was in the engineering world, and in business analysis, there are major problems with commerce, and enterprise, created by the application of corporations. The concept of holding companies, bank financing, and stockholders, all who are removed from the actual enterprise, in my conclusion, creates problems. One of the miracles of America’s beginnings was the corporate catastrophe of Caribbean Corporations, which led to this nation, rejecting corporations, was one of the foundations of strength that created the wonder…once…of the American form of enterprise. If one reads the Communist Manifesto, and the ‘Harry Potter’ of Marx’s fantasy, ‘Das Capital,’ which makes J.K. Rowling a realist. The conundrum is that in America, with the foundations of the most…known to now…even with the tripartite of Banks, Corporations, and the congress and tax laws, applying slavery to the society, the best known, is unknown, while academia is indoctrinating our society with socialism, communism, and government slavery, subsidized by the same government. To make is more incomprehensible is government allows students to put themselves in the debt of slavery to advance this instruction of anti-American indoctrination. Sadly, as the identification have been so corrupted, and the choices of communist, socialist, or corporate capitalist are really by application the same, makes me wonder what would I call myself. The closest thing of my choice, is personal liberty…which is unknown in any society today…and that commerce of free-choice is the best form of a society having any economic activity. As for government, the idea, the vision of a Republic with independent sovereign states, as America was designed, and enumerated central planning of government would be what I have come to conclude is the only way to have a government, and reject the central planning of state totalitarian sovereignty. Governments, since the first government, rejected individual liberty. It has been unknown in the empirical history of mankind, but as Marx was a dreamer of, I’d say we all can have a vision of our own utopia.

Are you a Communist, Socialist or capitalist and why? I do not subscribe to the emotive definitions of USA right wing extremists snd propagandists. I am a Christian, therefore I subscribe to communalism as an ideal (Acts 4:32–35). I am a Christian, therefore I subscribe to a socialised society (Mt 25:31–46). I am a Christian, therefore I do not subscribe to the employment of usury which “capitalism” is fully dependent upon, and which is condemned by the three major Abramic religions = Judaism, Christianity & Islam. What is referred to in the USA as “Capitalism” is in fact the usury of individualistic monetarists. The premise, is that the many will be exploited for the sole benefit of the very few. It is the worst of all systems and has historically only ever culminated in social & economic decline. The reason Donald Trump advocated “Lets make America great again” is as everyone on the planet can observe, the USA is in social & economic decline because of its pursuit of individualistic monetarism. Modern business in the creation of the Corporation and the Finance Industries (Banking & Insurance) employs the socialised precepts of voluntary collectivism. Since the rise of the corporation, the worker (the means of production) can acquire shared ownership in their enterprises, thus directly benefiting in their efforts (cp. 1 Thess 3:10–12). Also the universal suffrage movements of the 19th & 20th centuries have led to a decline in the individualistic monetarists (“Capitalists”) ability to exploit the worker. Their influence declines as the worker is given participation in government, and laws are enforced to prevent their exploitation. Also, those who hoard money(individualistic monetarists) have little value in a technological world, where collective organisation can readily raise the capital needed to build an enterprise, and where intellectual capital has exceedingly greater value to the world community than money.

I’m a capitalist. I’ve seen how it works, and how the absence of it causes the system to get inefficient and wonky. I’ve always been an entrepreneur without really knowing what that was, how it worked. I just felt curious about the angles and motivations of people who were successful. When I say successful, I don;t mean wealthy, I mean people who can create machines and systems that are nearly self sufficient. Systems that created more energy than they consumed. I’ve known more people who were “successful” who were always broke, but had their commitments paid down and debts easily leveraged. I’m also for a greater input from the social matrix… making decisions and commitments that give the most freedom to the most people. Some may call that “socialism” When we work together through some type of ideology, whether it be re;igious or “tribal” or just being part of the human race, we can evolve very quickly to meet new goals If i were to choose a pure communism, i would absolutely have to give into that god, ideology or bible on how things should be run and rules to make it run on the tracks. I do not trust “That” really exists. It’s a utopia. What works right now, will not be how it runs 20 years from now. How do you evolve, if you’ve given into that god, ideology or bible today? you probably won’t. If you do, it will be painful. The people who were lucky to prosper, will fight change. The people who weren't will fight TO change. If you give them something to exchange and bargain with the hunger and satiation by each individual will allow it to happen as it needs to happen. Let us have constitutions and regulations without praying to their gods and confining ourselves to their tired bibles. Let us discuss. Let us vote. Let us exchange for our mutual benefits.

I'm a capitalist and before I tell you why, let me differentiate between communism and socialism. Definitions : It is very likely to note that socialism slightly differs from communism in such a way that in a socialist society, property and wealth distribution is not owned by the state but by the community. Communism is just an extreme version of socialism which usually borrows or re-creates some of its features. [1] Now that we've got it out of the way, let me explain why I'm not only a capitalist, but capitalism matters. Structuring of capitalism. In a capitalist state, the means of production are controlled by the individual rather than the state. This gives a person greater freedoms to control his way of life by producing what he wishes.  The person can also wish to choose his own high quality products and even improve his standard of living by selling his products for a profit, thus increasing his wealth and quality of life. [2]  What is even better is that wealth decisions are made made by the individual, which means that he or she has a choice to freely invest in any market he desires and, through competitive markets accumulate as much wealth as possible. [3]  Furthermore, the great individualist nature given by it provides great incentives, not only for the rich but also middle class people. This gives him the opportunity to make a great product choice which will benefit him as well as opt to produce if no choice is fit for him.  The resultant structure of the free market gives it more incentive to invent, innovate and invest which not only make life better but also easier. It also creates a win-win situation whereby the rich get more wealth and the poor higher quality products.[4] The structure given by the market enables it not only to give freedoms for wealth productivity but also for other freedoms as well. Freedoms such as freedom of speech, freedom of religion and freedom of association are only found in most countries that possess a truly capitalist model. The problem with communism's model. Communism's structure claims to cater for the needs of a society by equally distributing wealth to the poor. [5]  This has proved to be difficult as communists have failed to create the necessary incentives for wealth to distribute. This, further more, leads to continuous cycles of power and wealth consolidation, tyrannisation and eventually societal backwardness.  Many of the Communist states established had either failed to realize this problem or responded to it wrongly, thus solidifying their control of wealth and eventually this lead to poverty. [6]  This has followed time and again across all Communist states. This is no wonder capitalism has able to do way better than it in every aspect of economics. This is due to the fact that : Over a billion people have lifted themselves from poverty due to capitalism's applications in former socialist areas.The free market has led to the growth of various national economies, many of which have little to no natural resources. E.g.: Hong Kong.The innovative nature of the capitalist model has led to the increasing of living standards, quality of life and wealth creation. Since the 20th century, capitalism has grown global life expectancy by almost 2 decades.Communism has ruined more countries than any other ideology, including Nazism. Estimates are that over a billion people's lives were ruined and about 100 million people ‘s lives were killed.This, among many other things is why capitalism matters over any other ideology. Yet people still blame capitalism for the world's problems. It is highly ignorant of those who have expressed this sentiment. No politico-economic system in history has ever proved its value so eloquently or has benefited mankind so greatly as capitalism—and none has ever been attacked so savagely, viciously, and blindly. The flood of misinformation, misrepresentation, distortion, and outright falsehood about capitalism is such that the young people of today have no idea (and virtually no way of discovering any idea) of its actual nature.” AYN RAND. Th Footnotes[1] Communism vs Socialism - Difference and Comparison[2] Capitalism - Wikipedia[3] Discover The True Nature of Capitalism[4] What Are the Advantages of Capitalism?[5] Communism - Wikipedia[6] The Economic Collapse of the Soviet Union

I am a democratic socialist and a reformist. I am a socialist because i believe that capitalism is destructive to human spirit. In a world where most workers don’t own the tools of their trade (“the means of production”), a worker is in fact reduced to the status of a russian serf who can choose their master but cannot choose not to have one. I am convinced that the one who plows a field should own it, and in turn he who owns the field should be the one who plows it. Democratic because i don’t see how socialism can be anything but democratic. I was born in a country that was socialist by name because the workers owned the means of production and all that on paper, but in fact had no say about how they should operate. It didn’t help workers much. Once their basic needs were satisfied they’ve lost all their enthusiasm and fallen into apathy as they knew they had little control over their lives. And they couldn’t even choose their masters as the authoritative state owned everything. Tash Lai's answer to What do you think of 21st century socialism, is it possible to find a way to implement it in the world and specifically in western countries? Reformist, because i really do want to distance myself from those who wish for an instant change right now, today, with little understanding of what they are going to do after they’ve overthrown the government and little concern for the majority who neither understands their goals nor is ready to accept them. I do however believe that, and it is especially true for Russia, modern society is too obedient and that sometimes it is necessary to break a few windows. The oppressed minority has the right to resort to violence if nothing else works. Or if the government wages an agressive war and denies doing so, people have the right to force it to stop, begin an investigation, and punish those responsible. But it doesn’t mean you should break all the windows and burn the house while so many people are still inside.

I am a Capitalist, for the most part. To be clear about definitions here (because there have been a lot of misconceptions going around, especially about Socialism): Capitalism is a system in which private entities own the means of production and trade, for the purpose of profit.Socialism is a system in which social entities own the means of production and trade.Communism is a system in which all property is publicly owned, each person works according to his or her abilities and is paid according to his or her needs, and this system is accomplished through violent class war.I am a Capitalist because I believe in the power of merit and I use benchmarking to look at how various economies around the world operate and what their successes and failures represent. The merit part comes from incentives. In a Capitalist system, you are richly (sometimes too richly) rewarded for taking risks and pursuing innovation. In non-Capitalist systems, such actions (which can produce astonishing progress) are not incentivized, which can result in stagnation and lost opportunities, both for individuals and for society. The benchmarking part comes from this: the most successful countries in the world, in terms of metrics that include wealth, social mobility, economic mobility, health, happiness, and productivity, are all Capitalist. They are also all Social Democracies (something that many in the US refer to as Socialism, which is incorrect). In practice, I am not a pure Capitalist though. If you take a good look, you see that when each of the three systems is unleashed without control, they quickly eliminate their own advantages: When Capitalism is unleashed without control, the wealthy and powerful seize the means of production. They monopolize and organize to eliminate competition, which allows the owner class to dictate the terms of the market (as in, it’s no longer a free market). They can then charge the maximum for their goods and services, compensate their workers at the bare minimum, and hoard the fruits of everyone’s labor. You can see that the advantages of Capitalism, which include innovation and social mobility, are severely curtailed by what amounts to a merchant aristocracy. It’s true that some hard-working and clever souls can break into that kind of system…but many who would succeed in a more balanced system are left destitute…many opportunities are missed. Look into the late 19th and early 20th centuries to see what this looks like.When Socialism is unleashed without control, it simply replaces the current upper class (whether aristocratic or capitalist) with a state-based one. This is because even though Socialism, like many other systems, can be applied in a limited way (I’ll get to that), it is often associated with total social control (via the state) of the means of production. This kind of centralized control benefits whoever is in charge and eliminates any kind of market pressure, which leaves consumers powerless. And, as mentioned before, personal incentives for innovation largely vanish.Communism is definitely the worst of the three because it actively pushes for violence. It rapidly replaces an existing system (whether aristocratic or capitalist) with one that is technically Socialist but goes further by dictating how compensation works and eliminating private property. This has an even worse effect on personal incentives. And, as with a fully Socialist economy, it simply replaces the existing upper class with a new one.An interesting point here is that many of these “pure” systems have worked dramatically well when first introduced, allowing for great advances and riches…until the detriments built up. So, given the above, you can probably tell that I’m a Socially Democratic Capitalist. I believe (and I find that this belief is well-supported by data) that measured state involvement in the market is necessary to keep Capitalism in its best state. I’m not a Communist because it advocates violence and requires a major shift in government, economy, and society. I’m not a Socialist mostly because of the incentive problem…but I do think that limited Socialism can be a good thing. What I mean by that is that some companies might be better off as cooperatives (i.e. controlled by all of the employees) or as partially (or majority) owned by the workers. This is technically Socialist…but because they are a self-contained private entity, it is also Capitalist. As a final note, things like universal healthcare, robust safety nets, government regulations, taxpayer-funded infrastructure, and taxpayer-funded education are not Socialist. You could make an argument that taxpayer-funded education is but I think it would be an uphill battle. Thanks Richard for the A2A!

I am a (democratic free market) Capitalist. It’s the only framework that gives you the most personal freedom and the ability to enjoy the full reward of the work you do for others or yourself. What it not automatically does is keeping predatory types (*) in check. But neither communism nor socialism or any other social-economic system does that. This requires permanent vigilance and a framework that constantly watches out to keep checks and balances working or how I put it, upholds the three pillars of a sustainable society - transparency, cooperation and competition. Adam Smith on this problem in the economic realm, 250 years ago: “The interest of the dealers [=monopolists, predatory types], however, in any particular branch of trade or manufacture, is always in some respects different from, and even opposite to, that of the public. To widen the market and to narrow the competition, is always the interest of the dealers. To widen the market may frequently be agreeable enough to the interest of the public; but to narrow the competition must always be against it, and can serve only to enable the dealers [=monopolists, predatory types], by raising their profits above what they naturally would be, to levy, for their own benefit, an absurd tax upon the rest of their fellow-citizens.”&“The proposal of any new law or regulation of commerce which comes from this order [=monopolists, predatory types], ought always to be listened to with great precaution, and ought never to be adopted till after having been long and carefully examined, not only with the most scrupulous, but with the most suspicious attention. It comes from an order of men [=monopolists, predatory types], whose interest is never exactly the same with that of the public, who have generally an interest to deceive and even to oppress the public, and who accordingly have, upon many occasions, both deceived and oppressed it.” The same applies to politics. Please ask yourself why ‘socialist’/’communist’ countries upon establishing themselves start to kill, exile or suppress political competition/opposition?! Democracy doesn’t do that. Free market capitalism itself doesn’t prohibit competition to enter a market.The opposite is right in the definition even:“Capitalism is an economic system based on the private ownership of the means of production and their operation for profit. Characteristics central to capitalism include private property, capital accumulation, wage labor, voluntary exchange, a price system, and competitive markets.” Anti competitive rules and involuntary exchanges are being enforced by society and its force/power, not by the economic system. Democracy rests this force/power with a democratic framework, which on paper contains checks and balances; or in other words - transparent, cooperative and competitive rules on how this force/power is wielded/controlled without privileges for any special group.But that only works if society (by accident or not) does not create power- and resourceful entities (via rules that create economic or political monopolies) that then start to influence politics or civil servants for their personal benefit. And as chance has it, there is actually just such a mechanic right at the core of all our democratic capitalist/socialist societies, that no one is talking about and 99.9% are completely ignorant of (even the ones profiting from it), but which does exactly that..Joan Spark's answer to When did most of the world switch to fiat money, and why did it happen? ———————————————————— *) predatory types are individuals or organizations who through force/power make you do things that you don’t want to do. They do not adhere to the principle of ‘voluntary exchange’, they oppose it.The only thing that keeps them from dominating is transparent competion with other predatory types IMHO.Any society that allows or enforces monopolies will sooner or later find, that those predatory types take up those niches and will dominate and successively destroy that society as through their action they acquire all resources of that society, which leaves only revolting to the rest of it. Joan Spark's answer to If there is economic class warfare in the US, which class is winning, and why? Joan Spark's answer to Why should I hate free markets?

I’m a Voluntaryist. People often describe governmental systems as socialist, communist, or capitalist, saying that a particular country has a “capitalist government,” or a “socialist government.” Communism and Capitalism are terms that actually describe economic systems, which, in theory, can be independent from government. Socialism is more likely a governmental system by which industries are socialized. When government is involved in the economy, authority and coercion is added to the mix. The question to be asked is no longer whether or not one prefers communism or capitalism, it’s whether or not you prefer more authority or less. Government uses force (by taxation) to implement any of its decisions. For instance, every time you get a paycheck after working in the US, you will see that money was pulled out for Social Security. Regardless of whether or not it works effectively, there are many US citizens who would rather not pay into social security, just as there are many US citizens who don’t want their tax payer dollars subsidizing certain industries. Once the government has mandated something, there is no choice. If you refuse, you will be punished. If you don’t vote, welp, you’re still mandated to follow the laws that the elected candidates spew into the system. You’re told that taxation is the price that you have to pay for living in civilized society, yet you didn’t chose to be born into a system that uses force. You’re told that you imply your consent to the system if you vote in the system’s elections, but let’s say that one candidate wants to commit genocide against the particular group that you associate with, and you want to vote against them. Voting is self-defense in some cases. They’ll say you consent if you drive on the system’s roads, but you also need to use the roads in order to vote, or obtain medical services, if need be. Not using their roads would limit your ability to participate with the civilized society of which you may benefit by providing services or charity. There is no social contract that we signed which gave the government consent to the atrocities that some face, yet we are all told in Government 101 class that “the consent of the governed” is necessary for the legitimacy of government. It is my belief that voluntary societies are the only ones that are ethical and effective. We enter into many contractual and consensual agreements with other parties all the time. It’s only your fault if you don’t read the terms & conditions provided! If one wanted to enter into a contract with other people who desired a distributive system akin to Social Security, one could, and it would be much more effective as well. There would be many choices too, and if there wasn’t a group with the policies that one desired, they could create a better one with hopes that other people would see why theirs is better as well. If one desired social distribution, they could contract into a system that distributes much like socialism, and if one desired a system by which the only distribution occurring was the distribution that naturally occurred by the market, they could contract into that system. Both would get fair amounts of participants as well, because yes, people have differing values, and that is precisely why coercion by government is discriminatory, and precisely why a free society is the only ethical option.

I am a mainland Chinese who received education in the US. I name myself a pragmatic socialist. Economically, I support capitalism with government oversight. A pure capitalistic society will be hell on earth. There will not be social warfare - (disabled, old, or sick people will be left to die since they don’t contribute financially), no oversight on environment protection (pandas and koala will be killed since it cost more to protect them), and no justice (rich people can pay to get out of jail while poor can’t). No country to date has pure capitalism. Similarly, a pure communist or socialist country will also be hell. Pure socialism entails social ownership of the means of production. We have seen over and over again when people live in a pure social/state ownership country, they don’t work. My grandparents lived through communnist China where everyone gets same payment and living conditions. My grandpa said he saw people standing/sitting by the fields and literally let the crops die. When you have a collective of farmers have no problem letting crops die, you get famine, scientific stagnation, and financial disaster. Human condition (or the vast majority I should say) always wants to put in as little effort as possible when there is no rewards. Deng Xiao Ping said no matter it is a black or white cat, as long as it can catch mice, it is a good cat. I completely support this sentiment. I believe in a moderate form of socialism that encourages economic growth.

I’m not any of those, I’m a social democrat. In other words, I’m part socialist and part capitalist. I believe in a regulated market economy, where the state directly controls and runs key services like the armed forces, police, emergency services, health and social care, social security, prisons and probation, libraries, museums, education, and train and bus services. It should also own the energy and communications infrastructure. This is because I believe the profit motive and price mechanism are flawed, though necessary. In the UK at the moment, we are experiencing the painful failure of the neo liberal obsession with private ownership. This is being played out in private care homes and mental health units where vulnerable people are being tortured and abused. We’re seeing it in the failure in our part privatised rail network and in the decline in bus use, when we desperately need to cut carbon emissions. The Huawai security scandal also demonstrates that an unlimited market economy can threaten national security. The state also has a role to play in research and development and innovation. It should help industries restructure, and not let areas decline, and people go to waste. Yes, developing an effective ‘industrial policy’ is challenging, but without it we create anger and inequality. Neo liberalism doesn’t lead to healthy economies, but to inflated assets and stagnant, shrinking markets as the rich get richer and the poor, poorer, and the middle classes are squeezed. Ultimately, unregulated capitalism ends up with fascism and war. Beyond the state sector, the economy should be largely socially owned by individuals and communities, using co-ops and mutuals. The financial sector needs to be restructured and made accountable. Big business shouldn’t be making the most important decisions in a democracy. A lot of people in the United States confuse socialism with social democracy. Social democrats actually oppose socialism because we understand the weaknesses of the state and the importance of private property, initiative and individualism. Socialism promises ‘one size fits all’ easy answers. It seems mainly to lead to economic stagnation and authoritarianism. No one said getting the balance right between private and public was ever going to be easy. But we need to ditch false neo liberal assumptions and start to rebalance our economies in favour of the people, not big business. We also need to learn from the big failures of the left in the past and build something new and better, not repeat the mistakes the left has made since the time of the Jacobins.

I’m a capitalist because I have seen the failures of communism and socialism time and time again. All one must do is study the various government cycles to see the effects the size and scope of government power have on the majority. You will find two common occurrences. 1. highly socialistic or communistic societies don’t last very long from a relative standpoint, several generations at best and they never do what is in the best interest of the majority, instead, benefiting special interests and/or the ruling class themselves. Castros Cuba and Lenin's Soviet Union as examples of the latter. The entire concept of government is to allegedly do what is in the best interests of the majority, and neither socialism or communism have even done this. As Thomas Jefferson stated, “that government is best which governs least” and boy it seems he was right on the money. Before their deaths, both he and Adams were already disappointed by the short history of the ruling class and their endeavors to utilize taxation and the majorites wealth for their own special interests. I fear as long as governments exist, the pockets of the majority will always be pilfered by those in power and redistributed to their special interests. There are really only the three systems as you noted in your question so if two of them always fail, then you really have only one, however imperfect, left to go with. Current day Zomia in SE Asia and the Irish Celts from about 650 AD to 1650 AD are two examples of anarchist societies; with no government force or coercion. They obvious are and did govern themselves individually. The Irish are said to have had family structures where heads of households worked together voluntarily to achieve social goals such as defense and mitigation of disputes and they were the most prosperous civil society in the whole of Europe until they were finally overthrown by the Monarchs of Europe around 1650. We got them back though some 50 years or so later, didn’t we, with the American, French and British revolutions and 70 years or so later with the abolition of slavery. Obviously, we may have won some huge battles for liberty, but we have not yet won the big one.

I am a Constitutionalist - a believer in a proper people’s Constitution that is capable of holding our elected representatives to account and a Constitution that will promote an honest political system that is less corruptible by money, judges, and lawyers. A system that will promote an egalitarian society based on a mixed economy where a Government is designated to provide the nation with what can be classified as the “essential services” to cover the “needs” of the people while the private sector can provide for the “wants” in a fair, honest and safe manner. I believe that politics should never be allowed to become a career and every politician should be limited to no more than two or three consecutive terms in office. I believe that the Supreme Court should be denied the ability to make law and that every decision of the Supreme Court must unanimous. If unanimity can’t be reached the problem must be handed back to Congress to resolve. All split decisions are flawed decisions because they are based on personal opinions, bias, upbringing, prejudices, and politics. They are never based on the proper legal interpretation of the way the law is written. No small group of unelected people should ever be allowed to assume the intent and meaning of a law, let alone the Constitution, and thereby usurp the responsibility and authority of Congress. If a law, and a Constitution, cannot be read and understood by any reasonably educated person then it is very poorly written. A nation’s Constitution should be made a compulsory subject in the curriculum of every High School in the nation. I also believe no person should ever have the power to veto the will of Congress nor should any single person have executive authority to override Congress or impose their own personal views. The only executive authority a Head of State should have, in their role as Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces, should be to declare war if the nation were to come under military attack by a foreign Government. All other military deployments, in any role, should be the responsibility of Congress.

I am a Marxist, which makes “communist” and “socialist” somewhat interchangeable terms (though one may, through this lens, also view “socialism” as an intermediate phase of societal development on the path to “communism”…wherein lie more than one devil in the details I’m afraid….). My goal, as Marxist, is working class ownership of the “means of life”. Why? Because I think economic power should be as decentralized and democratically managed as possible, and that people should have as much say as possible in the things which affect them most (like making a living….). As a Marxist, I am not opposed to “free trade”, which existed since time immemorial, and which can be formalized as “Commodity produced for exchange—via Money—for another Commodity”: C-M-C. What I am opposed to is a system (which I call “capitalism”—or Kapitalism with a “K”, if you like) which is characterized by private (minority) ownership of the means of life under conditions of market competition, and which prioritizes the maximization of profit, and which allocates labor and resources accordingly: Money is invested in Commodities for the overriding goal of gaining MORE Money: M- C - MM (or M’, i.e. “M prime”). Why am I opposed to a “ M-C-M’ ” system? Because the goal of capital accumulation, while tending to create a certain kind of material abundance (Marx eloquently praises capitalism’s productive and innovative capacity), is incapable of meeting needs which cannot appear in the market as “demand”, and it depends on endless growth (like cancer, or like a Ponzi scheme) for its continued survival as a system; and because private, minority ownership of the means of life alienates the vast majority of people from control over that most basic of human life support: production. That, anyway, are some of the reasons I am a communist (in the Marxist sense of the word—not the Stalinist sense of the word, which is the Orwellian opposite of what Marx meant by it). Why “communism” per se (as opposed to the more “intermediate”—and frankly “fraught”— “socialism”)? That is, why (using the Marxist sense of the word) a condition of society free from State coercive power, where individual people meet each other’s individual variable needs using their distinct and variable individual abilities? Because it seems like “heaven on earth” to me (as close as earth can get to heaven, anyway). As a Christian, this seems like a good thing to me: “And all that believed were together, and had all things common; and sold their possessions and goods, and parted them to all men, as every man had need” (Acts 2:44–45). There are many devils on many proposed paths of how to get “there”…. But “there” seems like a lovely place to me.

This is always a fraught issue. Given the varied meanings these words have and the many assumptions that people make about them, I find that labelling myself generally produces immediate misunderstandings. If by ‘capitalist’ is meant someone who supports, defends or apologises for capitalism (in any definition of that term), then I am not a capitalist. If by ‘communist’ is meant someone who advocate the politics of Lenin, Stalin, Trotsky, Mao, Castro, Kim Jong-un, etc, or bases their politics on the states and actions they are associated with, then I’m not a ‘communist’ If by ‘socialist’ is meant someone who is a follower or supporter of Labourist or social democratic politics, who actively pursues reforms of capitalism, or who actively advocates nationalisation of businesses, or health or welfare programmes, then I’m not a socialist. If I’m to label myself, I’ll have to qualify the terminology. The closest I can come is to say that I’m a Marxian, non-market socialist. Why? I’m not a supporter of capitalism because its enormous capacity to go on increasing the quantity of goods in the shops is not` sustainable and is outweighed by its failings: the system is wasteful, it is exploitative, it is prone to major conflict; it ties down the majority of people to a life of servitude to others; it is unstable; it operates between very narrow tolerances, and it is uncontrollable. The bottom line is that it is incapable of meeting human social need. I’m not a supporter of ‘communism’ in the sense described above. It is better described as a form of ‘state capitalism’. It therefore suffers from all the same flaws as private capitalism. I’m not a supporter of Labourism or Social Democracy, because these are merely ways of attempting to manage or reform capitalism in the mistaken belief that it can be managed or reformed to the benefit of working people. Trying to make capitalism work in the interests of working people is like trying to make the slaughterhouse work on behalf of the cattle. It is a futile endeavour and does nothing to remedy the system’s inherent flaws. The only solution I can currently see to the problems of capitalism are to dispose of it in its entirety. Whether that will happen or not is down to the mass of working people. If it doesn’t then I don’t have much hope for the future.

I am a capitalist, first and foremost. Having said that, I believe that there is absolutely a role for socialist policies in a capitalistic society. In the U.S., for example, we have an interstate highway system which is routinely used in the distribution of goods and services. But that highway system was built and paid for, and is continuously maintained, with taxes. So, our interstate highway system is, without doubt, socialist. And there is nothing wrong with that. It is perfectly acceptable to mix socialism with capitalism. In fact, there are many privately owned, for-profit, fully 100% capitalist businesses in the U.S. that benefit a great deal from our socialist interstate highway system. They also benefit from our socialist police and fire departments. And many would benefit a great deal from a more socialist approach to health care and education. I am a capitalist. But I recognize that there are some things that are just better and more efficiently done collectively. What the U.S. needs to do is stop listening to the propaganda of the rich, who would like to find a way to put more and more money into their own pockets. Instead, we need a strong but honest conservative party, and a strong but honest liberal party. And we need those parties to work together for the good of the majority of Americans.

The foundation of all natural rights is first and foremost the right of self ownership. This means nobody can enslave you, control your thoughts or how you express them and to hold any belief system one wishes and to exercise freely all the benefits the right of self ownership confer. Stemming from the foundational right, the right to maintain and improve one's condition and subsequently to own property to use and dispose of as one sees fit must follow. Barring intrusion upon the rights of another, the individual is sovereign and inalienable from the afore mentioned rights. This is the freedom we all seek but only a few fully enjoy. The more the freedom of the individual is protected the better society as a whole performs. Most Western civilizations have embraced this concept and have been the most successful in all the world in producing goods and services that better people's lives, improve their general condition and reduce poverty. The general term for this is the Free Market. Capitalism is only a facet of the market but it has produced much of the success in creating wealth at all levels. In opposition and often direct conflict with free market societies both socialism and communism with all the variants of them have never achieved success. Government alone holds the monopoly on force and coercesion. It is also true that slavery can only exist when it is condoned by government and theft can be made legal by the wording of law. When elites decide for themselves that they see a better way for the general conduct of society they must enlist the support of government to impose these ideas on the people. It is easy to demonize the successful when the majority are not as capable of creating the wealth and prosperity that the ambitious and fortunate few have done. Envy and greed are used to justify preying upon the wealthy and those with less will support the idea that the successful owe them something more. It seems all too easy to win popular support for the idea that one can have more when no effort is required other than that one votes for it. Government with popular support from the people can then expand authority and control of more of the population. Taking from those that produce by threat of force is theft. Taking the fruits of one's labor for the benefit of another enslaved the laborer. Creating dependency on government for one's sustenance also creates a slave. Good government must protect the rights of the sovereign individual. This is freedom. Poor government exploits the people by infringing upon their rights and treating them as a collective to be controlled in every aspect of their lives. This is slavery. As a spectrum between freedom and slavery fall various forms of government. With freedom on the right and slavery on the left it is the Free Market that defines the right side of things and is where the most prosperous societies fall. These are the societies that people flee to. Socialism and communism represent the left side of the spectrum and those societies that lean in that direction have always been the least prosperous and most restricted. These societies are the ones that build walls to keep their people from fleeing. For myself the choice is clear, it will always be freedom.
